title: Entanglement
Exactly as you would expect from the author and title, this is a well-written, interesting, popular book about quantum physics, focusing on quantum entanglement and its implications
Quantum Mechanics and Experience

I cannot decide whether David Albert is a physicist who does philosophy or a philosopher who does physics. In either case, here he has written an excellent introduction to the conceptual puzzles of quantum mechanics. Although some math is used, any graduate of our course should be able to follow along without trouble
Speakable and Unspeakable in Quantum Mechanics
A collection of John Bell’s papers on the foundations of quantum mechanics
The Ghost in the Atom

This is probably the ¿nest accessible introduction to the various competing interpretations of quantum mechanics. Introduced by a 40-page introductory essay explaining the essential issues, the main part of the book is made up of transcripts of BBC interviews with 8 contemporary quantum physicists

container-title: In this book he does the impossible, presenting the theory of quantum electrodynamics in a form that anyone can understand
note: An indispensible book for laypeople—and, for that matter, for quantum physicists.
title: QED: The Strange Theory of Light and Matter
Feynman was at the same time a truly great physicist and a great explainer of physics

note: Feynman’s description of the ribbon demonstration (Lecture Fourteen) is on pages 56–59.
title: Elementary Particles and the Laws of Physics
This volume contains the two 1986 Dirac Memorial Lectures at Cambridge University, given by Feynman and Weinberg. Both lectures are challenging surveys of contemporary fundamental physics
The Quantum World
Ford, who used to be the director of the American Institute of Physics, has written an outstanding popular account of quantum theory and its impact on physics
Tompkins in Paperback

Mr. Tompkins is a bank teller who is dating the daughter of a physics professor. As he listens to the professor, he falls asleep and has astonishing dreams of a town where the speed of light is 30 mph, a jungle where quantum tigers diffract among the trees, and many other astonishing locales
Thirty Years that Shook Physics
A great account of the historical development of quantum physics from 1900 to
illustrated with the author’s inimitable cartoons. Gamow was involved in this story and knew all the principals very well, so this book is also ¿lled
Introduction to Quantum Mechanics
A widely used quantum mechanics textbook aimed at senior-level undergraduates in physics—not for the general reader, in other words, but a good resource for the most serious students
Quantum Reality
A lively, popular account of quantum physics, including the EPR argument and Bell’s theorem, together with a good discussion of various interpretations
The New Quantum Universe
A wide-ranging qualitative exploration of quantum physics, lavishly illustrated with magni¿cent diagrams and photographs
A Shortcut Through Time
A very readable introduction to quantum computers: how they work, what makes them so different, and what their ultimate importance might be
Programming the Universe

Subtitled A Quantum Computer Scientist Takes on the Cosmos, this book tackles big ideas of quantum theory, information, thermodynamics, and cosmology, all seasoned with Lloyd’s Àair for vivid explanation and amusing anecdote
Introducing Quantum Theory
This looks like a pocket-sized cartoon book
The Strange World of Quantum Mechanics
A slender but rewarding book based on Prof. Styer’s ¿ne course at Oberlin College. Spins, amplitudes, probability, entanglement, and more are given a very lucid and accessible treatment
Bohr and the Quantum Dilemma
This is a marvelous treatment of the development of quantum theory, the Bohr-Einstein debate, and beyond. Whitaker has a good sense for the conceptual issues at stake
